measured_by: Knowledge of Disability Legislation Survey – Australian Adaptation (KDLA)
justification: “Knowledge of Disability Legislation Survey -Australian Adaptation (KDLA)… The scale consisted of 14 items.”

topic_or_construct: Productivity perceptions of employees with disabilities
justification: “The measures of productivity perceptions of disabled workers … (Scherbaum, Scherbaum, & Popovich, 2005) included 7 items each. The productivity perceptions scale measures the degree to which a person believes that employees with disabilities tend to make a positive contribution to the workplace.”
“The helpfulness scale is designed to measure a person’s general willingness to positively interact with employees with a disability…”

topic_or_construct: Discomfort when interacting with people with disabilities
measured_by: Interaction with Disabled Persons Scale – Discomfort subscale
justification: “The measure of discomfort was drawn from the Interaction with Disabled Persons Scale (IDPS; Gething & Wheeler, 1992)… the main psychometrically defensible scale in the IDP was the discomfort scale.”
“Experience with accommodation requests was measured using a single item that was rated 0 = no experience … 3 = highly experienced.”

topic_or_construct: Contact with people with psychological disability
justification: “The measure of contact with people with a psychological disability was a three-item composite… The three items were summed to form an overall score.”
“For each vignette, participants responded to six items: (a) empathy: ‘This employee is someone with whom I can empathize’.”
“(b) legitimacy: ‘Irrespective of the accommodation, I believe this specific disability to be a legitimate disability’.”
“(c) necessity: ‘This specific accommodation is necessary for organizational productivity’.”

measured_by: Single-item rated cost scale (1 = very inexpensive to 5 = very expensive)
justification: “(d) rated cost: ‘What cost would you associate with this specific work accommodation?’ (1 = very inexpensive to 5 = very expensive).”
“(e) reasonableness: ‘This work accommodation request is reasonable’.”
“(f) granting: ‘Would you grant this specific work accommodation request?’ Response scales were 0 = no, 1 = yes.”
